This review provides evidence that integrating HIV prevention services with family planning services has a positive effect on contraceptive uptake and pregnancy outcomes in HIV-positive women. However, the evidence is not strong enough to conclude that this effect is sustained.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the reviews once assessed.]
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of oral penfluridol as a maintenance treatment for schizophrenia.
There is no evidence to support the use of antibiotics in the treatment of severe melioidosis.

Antibiotic treatment for acute sinusitis in adults is effective. Antibiotics appear to be more effective than placebo in improving symptoms at day 10. Further research is required to determine whether antibiotics are more effective in patients with more severe symptoms.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the reviewed review once assessed.]
PGE 3350 appears to be an effective treatment for chronic constipation. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether it is superior to other osmotic laxatives.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether anticholinergics are more effective than placebo in the treatment of nocturnal enuresis.
The available evidence is insufficient to determine whether IOL is beneficial or harmful for improving visual acuity in people with angle-closure glaucoma.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of massage therapy for chronic low-back pain.
The available evidence suggests that a 7-day regimen of melarsoprol-nifurtimox is more effective than a 14-day regime of oral nifurtIMox for the treatment of Trypanosomiasis.
Limited fluid intake during the first week of life in preterm infants reduces mortality and morbidity in the short term but not in the long term.

There is currently no evidence to support the use of botulinum toxin for the treatment of ALS/MND. However, this conclusion is based on a small number of patients, most of whom were recruited as part of a randomised controlled trial. Future trials should be of sufficient size and duration to detect clinically important differences in clinically important outcomes.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether or not prophylaxis of mucosal candidiasis in HIV-infected women is effective.
There is insufficient evidence to determine whether total disc replacement is superior to fusion in the treatment of chronic low-back pain or degenerative disc disease.
Concomitant radiotherapy with carboplatin improves overall survival and time to progression in locally advanced NSCLC. However, the quality of the evidence is low.

There is insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the effectiveness of Cash and Counseling. The results of this review should be interpreted with caution due to the limited number of studies and participants.
There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of motivational interviewing for smoking cessation. There is a need for larger randomised controlled trials with longer follow-up.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of autotransfusion to reduce the transfusion requirement in patients undergoing surgery.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of antiseptic regimens to prevent or treat bacterial infection in newborn infants.

There is some evidence that exercise therapy for people with chronic stroke improves walking function. However, the evidence is not strong enough to recommend the use of this intervention in everyday practice.

There is no evidence to support the use of stenting for LAD lesions. There is a need for further RCTs to evaluate the effects of stent implantation on mortality and other morbidity outcomes in LAD patients.

The results of this systematic review confirm that plasma exchange is an effective treatment for improving the disability of patients with monoclonal gammopathy. However, the evidence is limited by the small number of patients studied and the high risk of bias in the included trials.

There is insufficient evidence to determine whether the use of oxygen-derived free radicals in the management of advanced colonic cancer is beneficial or harmful. There is a need for well-designed, adequately powered, randomised controlled trials that evaluate the effects of oxygen scavengers in this population.
There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of interferon beta in the treatment of relapsing remitting MS.
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of antidepressive drugs in the treatment of trigeminal neuralgia.
Quetiapine appears to be an effective treatment for tardive dyskinesia. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether it is an appropriate treatment for people with schizophrenia.
Magnesium sulphate is effective in reducing the risk of pre-eclampsia and its complications, but there is insufficient evidence to recommend its use.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the effectiveness of early developmental interventions for preterm infants.

There is insufficient evidence to determine the effectiveness of ignition interlock license restrictions. The results of this review should be interpreted with caution because of the small number of offenders in the trials, the small sample sizes and the heterogeneity of the trials.
A single dose of paracetamol 1000 mg is an effective analgesic for moderate to severe acute postoperative pain.
Ciclesonide was more effective than budesonide in improving lung function and asthma symptoms in adults with mild to moderate asthma. However, it was not as effective as fluticasone.
SSRIs are effective in the treatment of depression. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether they are more effective than placebo.

There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of influenza vaccination in the routine care of elderly people in care homes.
[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the Review once assessed.]
There is no evidence from this review to support the use of low-force spinal manipulation therapy for women with primary dysmenorrhoea.
There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of pelvic pelvic irradiation for stage I or II cervical cancer.

Combining GnRH-a with IVF-ET for one or more cycles of ART significantly increases the live birth rate per infertile woman compared to the same protocol alone.


[Note: The four citations in the awaiting classification section of the review may alter the conclusions of the reviewed review once assessed.]
There is insufficient evidence to support the use of PFMT in men with incontinence following prostatectomy.
There is currently insufficient evidence to determine whether the use of rFVIIa to treat traumatic intracerebral haemorrhage has any effect on clinical outcomes.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of omega-3 supplements in the treatment of cachexia.
Topical phenytoin appears to be an effective, safe and cheap treatment for the healing of leprosy ulcers.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of local anaesthetics during colposcopy.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine the relative benefits and harms of surgical versus non-surgical retreatment.
There is insufficient evidence to recommend the use of visual feedback for the production of dental sounds. There is a need for more research in this area.

There is insufficient evidence to draw conclusions about the effectiveness of interventions to prevent child sexual abuse. There is a need for high-quality randomised controlled trials to evaluate interventions to reduce the risk of bias in randomised trials.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of primaquine as a first-line treatment for malaria in low-income countries. Further trials are needed.
There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine whether or not oral prophylactic antibiotics are beneficial for the prevention of endomyometritis after forceps delivery.
There is no evidence that bladder irrigation reduces bacteriuria, symptomatic urinary tract infection, or catheter obstructions in people with indwelling bladder.
The available evidence is insufficient to determine whether or not cryosurgery is effective in the treatment of patients with liver metastases. Further research is required.
Sodium reduction may have a short-term beneficial effect on blood pressure. However, the evidence is not strong enough to recommend the use of this intervention for the prevention of hypertension.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of masks to prevent surgical site infection in patients undergoing surgery.

Varenicline appears to be effective in promoting smoking cessation in people with stable smoking status. However, the evidence is not strong enough to support its use as a smoking cessation drug. The evidence for adverse effects is weak.

Anti-inflammatory drugs such as aspirin reduce the risk of colorectal cancer recurrence and polyps in patients with familial adenomatous polyposis. However, there is insufficient evidence to determine whether aspirin is beneficial or harmful.
There is no evidence to support the use of antibiotic prophylaxis for men undergoing prostate biopsy.

There is insufficient evidence from randomised controlled trials to determine the relative benefits and harms of LRT compared with other neurolysis treatments for patients with LRT. Further research is required to determine whether LRT is superior to other neuroleptic treatments for LRT-1.
There is no evidence from randomised controlled trials to support or refute the use of penicillamine for patients with primary cholangitis.
There is insufficient evidence to support or refute the use of dietary interventions to prevent weight gain during pregnancy.
